Graphical abstract Complete utilization of solar light in the photocatalytic reaction is of paramount importance for efficient conversion of solar light. Although NIR constitutes almost 50% of the solar energy, there are very few efforts towards its effective utilization in photocatalysis. The difficulty of NIR usage is its associated low energetic photons, which can lead to exciton generation only for low band-gap semiconducting systems, which is sometime not enough to initiate photocatalytic process. Moreover, these type of systems have very fast charge recombination process. Assembling one low band gap semiconductor with a wide bandgap semiconductor to form a nanohybrid heterojunction could be an efficient NIR harvesting photocatalyst. Herein, we report a novel CuS-ZnO nanohybrid, bound by a cysteine ligand, to exhibit efficient photocatalytic performance using the NIR fraction of the solar light spectrum. Raman spectroscopy and picosecond resolved studies have been carried out to confirm the electronic coupling of the nanohybrid. An improved photocatalytic activity towards degradation of methyl orange (MO) was observed by the nanohybrid compared to its individual counterparts (ZnO and CuS) under NIR light illumination. First principles investigations have guided us in obtaining an insight to the photocatalytic process. Computationally predicted band alignment implies that the nanohybrid forms a type II heterojunction. An increment of significant charge separation from the conduction band of CuS to those of ZnO is the key mechanism behind the enhanced photocatalysis. Keywords NIR harvesting FRET Photocatalysis Heterostructure DFT Spectroscopy 1 Introduction The rapid growth of global population and industrialization leads to water pollution due to toxic wastes from industry. Photocatalysis is a very promising technique to degrade the water pollutant by harvesting the solar light [1–4]. There have been significant developments of this field in the last 50 years [5]. Photocatalysis can be defined as acceleration of a reaction, in presence of catalyst which is activated by photon from a light source [3,6]. Since the discovery of photocatalysis [5] in 1972, a lot of research has been carried out to clean water by photocatalytic reaction using various heterogeneous photocatalyst [1–3,7–10]. Light absorption plays the most crucial role in the photocatalysis process. Solar light is the proficient energy source for the photocatalytic reaction to happen and its amount on Earth reaches every hour 480 EJ (1 Exa J =1018 J), which is 27 times more than that current yearly use of whole mankind [11]. Therefore, effective utilization of full solar spectrum can definitely solve the energy crisis on the earth. Solar spectrum constitutes of ˜4% UV rays, ˜46% visible rays and ˜50% near infra-red (NIR) light [12,13]. Although, NIR contains half of the solar spectrum, there are very few efforts to utilize this part of the solar spectrum as the corresponding low photon energy has very little efficiency to harvest the solar light [14,15]. TiO2 and ZnO are the two most widely used photocatalysts till date due to their excellent catalytic efficiency and low cost [4,16–20]. However, because of their wide band gap nature, they can harvest only UV light, which is only 4% of the complete solar light spectrum [2,17]. A great amount of research has been focused on utilizing more solar light for conversion to photo-chemical energy [13,21–23]. Several approaches (including introduction of noble metals, cationic substitutions, anionic doping, dye sensitization and surface modification) have been implemented to alter the band gap of the semiconductor [23,24]. This bandgap determines the portion of the solar spectrum to be utilized by the catalyst via photon absorption process, which determines the amount of energy that is converted to reactive species. Due to higher penetration power NIR light produces very high heating effect on the targeted object [25,26] which is another drawback towards its application in the field of photocatalysis. Hence, the main challenge of the NIR photocatalysis is to control the heating effect and utilize the low energy photon in a productive way so that it can be useful for photocatalysis. In spite of having many difficulties like low conversion rate of photon energy, the advantage of NIR is its high penetration ability and effective available time. As the wavelength is larger, the skin depth of the NIR light is longer, thus it can easily travel through dust, fog, thick smoke or human body. NIR can penetrate deep inside the river or drainage system where it can trigger the photocatalysis to remove pollutants from contaminant water. Another major advantage of photocatalytic reaction using NIR harvesting material is that the reaction can take place from dawn to dusk. Recently works have explored the possibility of harvesting NIR light and utilize it in the photocatalytic reaction [12,14,27–29]. To initiate a photocatalysis with solar energy as photon source, corresponding catalyst needs to have an absorption band above 1.23 eV [30]. A suitable combination of materials with appropriate band-gap can be effective to harvest NIR and thus can accelerate the photocatalysis [13,31]. So designing a nanohybrid which can utilize the NIR part of the solar spectrum and convert the energy to the photocatalysis is highly desirable in terms of full solar energy utilisation. Recently, semiconductor heterostructure formation has been a common approach of research in order to find efficient photocatalyst by maximizing solar spectra harvesting ability as well as enhanced charge carrier separation. This heterojunction can tune many electronic, magnetic, optical and many other properties [32–34] which can be very much advantageous for case by case applications. In our case, combined band-alignment of the heterostructure obtained via combination of NIR active material with an appropriate photocatalyst forms a charge transfer pathway that separates the photogenerated charge and also limits the recombination process. Copper sulfide (CuS) nanoparticles (NPs) have gained a lot of attention in recent years because they exhibit a strong absorption band in NIR region [35]. Due to this, CuS produces immense interest in the field of sensing, molecular imaging, photo-thermal therapy, solar cell, drug delivery, Li-ion battery, lubricant etc. [35–38]. Depending on environment and synthesis condition, different shape of covellite CuS (such as hollow sphere, plates, rods, wires, tube flower etc.) have been reported earlier [39–41]. Furthermore, preparation of CuS involves low-cost and easier methodology with respect to other reported NPs (i.e. Au, Ag), having optical absorption band in NIR region. Moreover, CuS shows better photo-stability for a long time compared to other NIR active NPs [42]. In addition CuS NPs are non-toxic under ambient conditions, which is prerequisite for environmentally friendly water cleaning technology. NIR absorption of CuS is manifested by the d-d energy band transition of the Cu2+ ion, which is not affected by surroundings or the solvent [43,44]. So it can work as a photocatalytic agent in any condition irrespective of surroundings. Although CuS is a potential harvesting agent of NIR, it is not used as a photocatalyst due to its high recombination rate of electron-hole pairs. If the recombination process can be arrested and the excited state charge can be separated by some means, that may lead to an improvement of photocatalytic process. In order to restrict the recombination rate and to generate long lived photo-generated electron, we have coupled the NPs with a wide bandgap semiconductor ZnO via a biocompatible ligand cysteine. ZnO is reported to be excellent wide bandgap semiconductor having higher binding energy (60 MeV), abundance in nature, non-toxic, low-costly, chemically-stable photocatalyst. ZnO is also biocompatible, biodegradable, and biosafe for medical and environmental applications [45,46]. The newly prepared nanohybrid can efficiently arrest the self-recombination of the electron-hole pairs of CuS. CuS has a natural tendency to form non-stoichiometric p-type semiconductor [47,48] with unique metallic conductivity, electrical and thermal property. So there is a possibility to get charge a transfer from CuS to ZnO through a newly engineered pathway between them. This gives us motivation to carry out the CuS-ZnO nanohybrid formation and investigation of the photocatalytic property in the near NIR region. Furthermore, to confirm the charge-transfer pathway we have performed first principles calculations using density functional theory. The calculated band alignment reveals formation of type II heterostructure in the nanohybrid. Upon NIR excitation, the electron in the excited state of CuS is instantly injected into the conduction band of ZnO which eventually leads to better charge separation. Herein, we report a wet chemical synthesis of novel CuS-ZnO nanohybrid. First, we prepare CuS NPs coated with a biological ligand namely cysteine (Cys-CuS). This ligand controls the size and shape of the CuS NPs. The prepared Cys-CuS NPs is spherical in nature with a mean particle size around ˜ 6 nm. In the next step, CuS NPs are attached with synthesized ZnO NPs to design the CuS-ZnO nanohybrid. The as-prepared system is characterized by various technique including scanning electron microscopy (SEM), transmission electron microscopy (TEM), high resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM) and X-Ray diffraction (XRD). Nanohybrid formation is confirmed by using Raman spectroscopy. The photocatalytic activity of the CuS-ZnO nanohybrid upon the irradiation of NIR light has been explored. It is observed that, this newly prepared nanohybrid gives better photocatalytic activity over the pristine CuS NPs in the NIR region. Using the Ab initio DFT calculation as implemented in Vienna Ab initio Simulation Package (VASP) [49], we have investigated the mechanism behind the enhanced photocatalytic activity of the composite nanohybrid. Atom projected density of states (APDOS) and optical properties of the systems are also calculated using first principles calculation. The predicted band alignment of the nanohybrid rationalises the enhancement of the charge separation and photocatalytic activity of the nanohybrid over pristine CuS. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Reagents Sodium carbonate (Na2CO3), Potassium chloride (KCl), Sodium hydroxide (NaOH) and Copper (II) acetate monohydrate ((CH3COO)2Cu, H2O) were purchased from Merck, Zinc Acetate dihydrate ((CH3COO)2Zn, 2H2O), L-Cysteine (C3H7NO2S), Sodium sulphide hydrate (Na2S, xH2O) were purchased from Sigma Aldrich, Polyethylene glycol PEG (Mw = 1000) were brought from Fluka. Usually, 0.12 mmol of L-cysteine was dissolved in 50 ml of deionized water. 10 mmol (CH3COO)2Cu was dissolved in 50 ml water ethanol mixture (1:1 v/v). This solution is then added to the above solution drop wise under constant stirring. After completely mixing of these two solutions, it is kept under vigorous stirring condition for next 30 min. The complete solution was then stirred vigorously using a magnetic stirrer, and the temperature is maintained at 80 °C for 2 h. After that the NPs were seperated out by centrifugation and washed several time with deionized water. 2.5 Synthesis of ZnO NPs ZnO NPs of various sizes has been synthesized using our previous work [20]. ZnO NPs of size ˜5 nm was prepared by using wet chemical method in ethanol. 20 ml 4 mmol zinc acetate dihydrate was heated in a beaker at 60 °C around 40 min. 20 ml 4 mmol sodium hydroxide solution was mixed drop wise in the heated solution. The mixture was then shaked in robust manner for 2 h at 60 °C. The resulting solution was preserved in a cool place until further use. 30 nm ZnO NPs were prepared using precipitation method. At first PEG (10% v/v) was put into a three neck round bottom glass. 0.05 mol zinc acetate dihydrate and 0.1 mol Na2CO3 was added together into the PEG solution. The solution was then mixed intensely for 2 h with a magnetic stirrer. The prepared NPs were settled as sediment at the bottom of the pot. It is then washed properly with double distilled water and ethanol. 2.6 Preparation of CuS-ZnO nanohybrid The as-synthesized ZnO NPs were taken in a glass beaker and dispersed in water, and then the dispersed solution was sonicated for 20 min to obtain a homogeneous ZnO solution in water. Briefly, 3 mmol Cys-CuS was dispersed in 10 ml deionized water by continuous stirring. pH of the solution was adjusted to slight basic upon drop wise addition of NaOH solution in it. 3 mmol ZnO is also dispersed in 10 ml water in another separate beaker. This solution is added drop wise in the Cys-CuS solution and stirred vigorously for 24 h and then separated by centrifugation. The supernatant was removed and the precipitated part was washed several time with distilled water and re-dispersed in water/ethanol for characterization. 3 Computational method First-principles spin-polarized density functional calculations are performed using Projector augmented wave (PAW) potentials for CuS, ZnO and cysteine attached CuS-ZnO nanocluster in a rectangular box of box size 23 × 23 × 40 Å3. The exchange-correlation interactions are treated by the generalized gradient approximation (GGA) with Perdew-Burke-Ernzerhof (PBE) exchange-correlation functionals using Vienna Ab-initio Simulation package (VASP) [49]. The cut-off energy for the plane-wave expansion is set as 500 eV. van der Waal’s interactions are incorporated in this calculation by using DFT-D2 method of Grimme [52], as implemented in VASP. The nanostructures are fully relaxed until the absolute value of force acting on each atom is less than 0.01 eV/Å. Keeping in mind the large box-size and the corresponding tiny Brillouin zone, we have employed only single k-point (Γ- point) for complete geometry optimization and electronic structure calculations using the Monkhorst–Pack mesh. Raman spectra collected from CuS, ZnO and CuS-ZnO nanohybrid in the wavenumber region of 350 − 650 cm−1 are depicted in Fig. 5 a. As evidenced from the figure, the spectrum shows a very pronounced peak at 472 cm−1 for CuS NPs, which corresponds to the covalent SS bond stretching vibration modes of CuS NPs [59]. Interestingly, after the formation of nanohybrid, the intensity of E2(high) mode is suppressed with respect to pristine ZnO, keeping other modes intact. This indicates a possibility of perturbation of the mode associated with defect centre. After the formation of nanohybrid, other peaks of CuS and ZnO remain the same, indicating a good retention of the ZnO and CuS structure and crystalline properties. It is found that upon addition of very little ROS initiator (H2O2) the catalytic activity increased (Fig. 6c) whereas the presence of ROS scavenger sodium azide (NaN3) stoped the generation of ROS. It was found that in presence NaN3 the photocatalytic activity of the the NP decreased, which corroborates the role of ȮH radicals in the photocatalytic process. Therefore, our results suggest the photocatalytic activity predominantly favours through reactive oxygen species which degrades the pollutants [67,68]. So, the photocatalytic process does not depend on external condition like temperature due to NIR light heating, rather the process is entirely dependent on the activity of photocatalyst under light exposure. 4.4 Modelling using ab initio calculations To understand the mechanism behind the enhanced catalytic activity in CuS-ZnO nanohybrid, we have investigated the electronic structure of nanohybrid using first principles calculations. ZnO nanoparticle system consists of 99-atom assembly of Zn50O49, placed in a rectangular box of size ˜23 × 23 × 40 Å3. The non-stoichiometry of ZnO cluster is due to the presence of single surface oxygen vacancy. A 90-atom Cu45S45 cluster and Cysteine attached CuS-ZnO nanohybrid are also placed in a rectangular box of same size. Using ab initio calculations, we have carried out an extensive analysis of electronic structure, spin polarization, charge transfer process and band alignment of CuS, ZnO and CuS-ZnO nanohybrid. The calculated atom projected density of states (APDOS) of CuS is shown in Fig. 7 a). Experimental results of prior section indicate that CuS is a low bandgap material, consistant with APDOS plot [69]. The non-zero DOS at Fermi level (E F ) leading to metalicity of the system is mainly contributed from 3d orbital of Cu and 3p orbital of S, which can be seen from the orbitally projected DOS plots of Fig. 7a. The APDOS of CuS NPs indicates that highest occupied molecular orbitals (HOMO) and lowest unoccupied molecular orbitals (LUMO) are mainly contributed by highly hybridized S-3p orbitals along with Cu-3d orbital, confirming covalent nature of the system [69]. Highly symmetric DOS of the up-spin and down-spin channel predicts the system to be non-spin polarized. ZnO NPs, a well-known wide direct bandgap semiconductor, are experimentally seen to be prone to have surface oxygen vacancies [20]. The APDOS of the cluster is presented in Fig. 7b. The valance band maximum of ZnO is predominantly contributed by O-2p states. Conduction band maxima equally hybridized by cationic Zn-4d and anionic O-2p states, some gap states are generated due to oxygen vacancy in ZnO cluster. Upon attachment with ZnO with a ligand cysteine, CuS-ZnO nanohybrid shows many interesting electronic modifications compared to the parent pristine systems. The heterostructure having CuS and ZnO nanocluster attached with a ligand Cysteine is shown in Fig. 9. The APDOS of CuS-ZnO nanohybrid is shown is Fig. 7c. In the heterostructure, the metallic character of CuS near E F remains unaltered. Interestingly, a significant amount of states have been generated due to cysteine near E F implying a possibility of charge accumulation therein. For the combined system, the E F shifts towards valence band stipulating a p-type doping in the system, indicating a possibility of charge transfer from CuS to ligand and ZnO. The charge density plot (Fig. 8 a) of nanohybrid confirms that there is an overlap of charge density of CuS, ligand and ZnO. It is clear that the edge states, where ligand is attached, are delocalized in CuS NPs and ZnO NPs, denoting the charge transfer possibility within the nanohybrid. CuS nanocluster and ZnO nanocluster individually shows no magnetization, as indicated by the APDOS Figure (Fig. 7c). After forming nanohybrid, due to mutual charge transfer interactions, the nanohybrid becomes magnetic. APDOS of the heterostructure shows asymmetry in up and down-spin channels near E F . The spin density distribution of the nanohybrid system can be seen in Fig. 8b, indicating magnetic moments are mainly distributed over the surface oxygen atom of ZnO nanocluster. Magnetic moments mainly originated from the d-orbitals of Cu and Zn and p-orbital of S and O. The schematic representation of theoretically determined energy band diagram of CuS-ZnO nanohybrid is presented in Scheme 2 . It is clear from the band alignment of the nanohybrid that it forms a type–II heterojunction. [70] When the nanohybrid is excited using NIR light, excited state electron of CuS is instantly injected into the conduction band of ZnO. As a consequence of this efficient charge separation within nanohybrid, we have observed enhanced photocatalytic activity. The calculated optical absorbance of CuS, ZnO and CuS-ZnO nanohybrid calculated using DFT as implemented in ATK software is depicts in Fig. 9 [53]. This result is consistent with the experimental absorption spectra. Calculated absorption spectrum shows a strong absorption band near NIR region which distributes from NIR toward far IR [71]. This result reveals that CuS is a potential NIR absorber. ZnO is a wide bandgap semiconductor which has an absorption in UV region. In the present case, we have dealt with ZnO with a surface oxygen vacancy (OVS). This ZnO NPs give an absorbance peak around ˜380 eV with is due to the transition from LUMO to HOMO. The OVS generates many midgap trap states resulting in a sharp absorption peak in the visible region of the absorption curve of ZnO NPs. These peaks are solely contributed by the transition between HOMO to trap states. In case of CuS-ZnO nanohybrid, the CuS NPs is attached to the ZnO through a ligand on the surface oxygen vacant state of ZnO. As a result of the decrement of the trap state, the absorption peak in the visible region due to oxygen vacancy state is subsided in the nanohybrid. The nanohybrid shows an absorption peak in NIR region mainly due to the contribution of CuS. The absorption spectrum of nanohybrid is completely different from its pristine identity. Charge density analysis is performed using the Bader method (R. F. W. Bader, W. Tang et al., E. Sanville et al., G. Henkelman et al.) [72]. The amount of charge transfer from one nanocluster to another can be predicted by Bader partitioning method where electron charge density in a certain volume (called Bader volume) around each atom is obtained. The boundaries of each atom are determined simply as the minimum point of the electron charge density between each two atoms, which is called Bader minima. Bader charge analysis predicts that, there is possibility of ˜ 25 unit (1.3%) bader charge transfer from CuS to the ligand and ZnO, which is consistent with the relative Fermi shift of CuS. This ground state charge separation, as shown in the band diagram of the nanohybrid, is an indication of the stability of formation of the nanohybrid. Based on the above analysis it can be concluded that, upon illumination of nanohybrid with simulated NIR light source CuS produces electron hole pairs. Due to its favorable electronic bandgap allignment, the excited state electrons are transferred to the conduction band of ZnO, as confirmed from our first principles theoretical study, which eventually reduces charge recombination process. Therefore efficient separation of charge carrier of the naohybrid favours dramatical improvement in photocatalytic activity under NIR light illumination in compare to its pristine counterpart. In presence of CuS-ZnO nanohybrid, the excited state electron transfer from conduction band of CuS to ZnO takes place. As a result of facilitated charge transfer, excited state electrons in the conduction band of ZnO reacts with dissolved oxygen present in water to form reactive oxygen species (ROS). This ROS can oxidise the toxic dye molecule to form non-toxic products like CO2 and H2O. A schematic diagram of the pathway of the photo-generated charge separation in the nanohybrid and subsequently dye degradation through the generation of reactive oxygen species is shown in Scheme 1. This highly efficient charge separation mechanism in the nanohybrid is mainly responsible for higher photocatalytic performance. 5 Conclusion In summary, a new NIR harvesting nanohybrid CuS-ZnO has been successfully prepared through a facile wet chemical synthesis and confirmed the formation using various techniques including picosecond resolved technique and Raman spectroscopy. Narrow bandgap of CuS in the heterostructure shows a strong absorption peak in the NIR region, which efficiently absorbs the NIR light. The enhance photocatalytic activity originated from the efficient excited state charge transfer from the conduction band of CuS to ZnO within the nanohybrid. The ground state charge transfer from CuS to nanohybrid has been calculated computationally using the Bader method. The work present here shows an innovative strategy to utilize the NIR light through the construction of heterostructure for photocatalytic degradation. The results are very much promising for full spectrum solar light harvesting and NIR driven photocatalytic activity. This novel work may catalyse the research on the harvesting and application of NIR solar light field towards a new direction. Acknowledgements T. K. M. thanks DST-INSPIRE for fellowship. P. coredata.dc:description: Complete utilization of solar light in the photocatalytic reaction is of paramount importance for efficient conversion of solar light. Although NIR constitutes almost 50% of the solar energy, there are very few efforts towards its effective utilization in photocatalysis. The difficulty of NIR usage is its associated low energetic photons, which can lead to exciton generation only for low band-gap semiconducting systems, which is sometime not enough to initiate photocatalytic process. Moreover, these type of systems have very fast charge recombination process. Assembling one low band gap semiconductor with a wide bandgap semiconductor to form a nanohybrid heterojunction could be an efficient NIR harvesting photocatalyst. Herein, we report a novel CuS-ZnO nanohybrid, bound by a cysteine ligand, to exhibit efficient photocatalytic performance using the NIR fraction of the solar light spectrum. Raman spectroscopy and picosecond resolved studies have been carried out to confirm the electronic coupling of the nanohybrid. An improved photocatalytic activity towards degradation of methyl orange (MO) was observed by the nanohybrid compared to its individual counterparts (ZnO and CuS) under NIR light illumination. First principles investigations have guided us in obtaining an insight to the photocatalytic process. Computationally predicted band alignment implies that the nanohybrid forms a type II heterojunction. An increment of significant charge separation from the conduction band of CuS to those of ZnO is the key mechanism behind the enhanced photocatalysis.
coredata.dc:title: A combined experimental and computational study on a nanohybrid material for potential application in NIR photocatalysis
